data.title: Spring TV 2019: Premiere dates for new and returning shows
data.meta_description: Find out when your favorites ("Game of Thrones"), new spinoffs ("Pretty Little Liars: The Perfectionists"), and ambitious miniseries ("Fosse/Verdon") premiere in the 2019 spring TV season.
data.text:
Whether it’s a new show or a returning favorite, the spring 2019 TV garden has plenty of options to choose from. Mark your calendars for the premiere of the eighth and final season of “Game of Thrones,” Jordan Peele’s revival of “The Twilight Zone,” a “Project Runway” makeover, more cat-and-mouse intrigue on “Killing Eve,” and a host of other options. Here are notable premiere dates for the spring TV season:

MARCH 8

“After Life”: Ricky Gervais stars in another series with darker tones than the comedies (“The Office,” “Extras”) that made him famous. In this one, Gervais plays a widower who’s not shy about letting everyone know he’s angry over his loss. (Streams on Netflix)

“Tin Star”: The British-Canadian drama starring Tim Roth and Christina Hendricks returns for a second season. (Streams on Amazon Prime Video)

MARCH 10

“American Gods”: The fantastical series inspired by Neil Gaiman’s book about the battle between old gods and new returns for Season 2. (9 p.m. Starz)

“Aretha! A Grammy Celebration for the Queen of Soul”: The late, great Aretha Franklin’s music is performed by stars such as Jennifer Hudson, Janelle Monae, John Legend and Celine Dion in a tribute concert. (9 p.m. CBS)

“The Case Against Adnan Syed”: The case that became famous because of the “Serial” podcast gets more attention in a four-part docuseries. The murder of Baltimore’s Hae Min Lee, and the conviction of her onetime boyfriend Adnan Syed, are again the focus, but director Amy Berg says the series will give greater attention to the teenage murder victim, and the issues surrounding the case. (9 p.m. HBO)

“Now Apocalypse”: Director Gregg Araki co-created this wild comedy-ish about good-looking young people in Los Angeles who are having a lot of sex, pursuing careers and figuring out whether there’s something weird going on with aliens. (9 p.m. Starz)

MARCH 11

“Punk”: A four-part docuseries exploring the roots and impact of the punk music scene. (10 p.m. Epix)

“Manhunt”: Martin Clunes (“Doc Martin”) takes a dramatic turn as a British detective trying to solve a series of murders. (Streams on Acorn TV)

MARCH 12

“MasterChef Junior”: The cooking competition that shows the softer side of shouty chef Gordon Ramsay returns for Season 7. (8 p.m. Fox)

MARCH 13

“SEAL Team”: The action series returns after a brief pause and picks up where it left off, in a new time slot. (10 p.m. CBS)

MARCH 14

“Project Runway”: With Heidi Klum and Tim Gunn off to do their own fashion-related project at Amazon, the design competition has gotten a makeover. Supermodel Karlie Kloss is the new host, designer Christian Siriano (a former “Project Runway” winner) is the mentor, and the judges are the veteran Nina Garcia, designer Brandon Maxwell, and journalist Elaine Welteroth. The competitors in Season 17, now back on Bravo, include Portland-based designer Sonia Kasparian. (8 p.m. Bravo)

“The Good Fight”: Michael Sheen (“Masters of Sex”) joins the cast of this “Good Wife” spinoff as an attorney with outrageous appetites and questionable ethics. Christine Baranski, Audra McDonald and Delroy Lindo are among the top-flight cast returning for Season 3. (Streams on CBS All Access)

MARCH 15

“Arrested Development”: Did you forget the comedy returned for Season 5 a while back? Well, here it is again, for the second half of that season. (Netflix)

“Catastrophe”: The ribald comedy-drama about relationships and parenthood returns for a fourth and final season. Rob Delaney and Sharon Horgan star. (Amazon Prime Video)

“Queer Eye”: The makeovers and more continue in Season 3. (Netflix)

“Shrill”: Aidy Bryant (“Saturday Night Live”) stars in a new series inspired by Seattle writer Lindy West’s memoir. The comedy-drama, which is set and filmed in Portland, stars Bryant as an aspiring journalist dealing with her own body image, a dysfunctional relationship, her friends, parents and her demanding boss (played by John Cameron Mitchell, of “Hedwig and the Angry Inch”) at an alternative newsweekly. (Streams on Hulu)

“Turn Up Charlie”: Idris Elba, best known for dramatic roles in “The Wire” and “Luther,” stars in a lighter-toned series as an underemployed DJ who gets a job as a nanny, looking after an 11-year-old girl. (Netflix)

MARCH 16

“Trading Spaces”: The home renovation revival returns for a new season. (8 p.m. TLC)

MARCH 17

“Billions”: The sharply written, superbly acted series about power struggles among the wealthy and well-connected in New York returns for Season 4. As the season begins, Chuck Rhoades (Paul Giamatti) has been booted from his high-profile position as U.S. Attorney, and hedge-fund Master of the Universe Bobby Axelrod (Damian Lewis) is scheming to get revenge on his former protégé-turned-rival, Taylor Mason (Asia Kate Dillon). (9 p.m. Showtime)

MARCH 18

“9-1-1”: The question, “What’s your emergency?” keeps being answered as the series returns for the rest of Season 2. (9 p.m. Fox)

“The Inventor: Out For Blood in Silicon Valley”: The ever-busy Alex Gibney (“Going Clear: Scientology and the Prison of Belief”) directs a documentary about Stanford dropout Elizabeth Holmes and Theranos, the company she founded that promised to be a major disrupter in health care. It didn’t work out that way. (9 p.m. HBO)

“The Fix”: Marcia Clark, who became famous for her unsuccessful prosecution of O.J. Simpson in the notorious double-murder trial, is an executive producer and writer for a new legal drama starring Robin Tunney as Maya Travis, a prosecutor who unsuccessfully prosecuted a movie star in a double-murder trial. Well, that sounds familiar. The retired Travis is lured away from her quiet life in rural Washington when the same star is suspected of another murder. (10 p.m. ABC)

MARCH 19

“Mental Samurai”: Rob Lowe hosts this bizarre series in which contestants have to answer (some pretty hard) questions, while also being lobbed about the stage in what looks like a showbiz version of a vomit comet. (9 p.m. Fox)

“The Village”: A new series about the bonds formed between the residents of an apartment building in Brooklyn. The cast includes Lorraine Toussaint, Dominic Chianese, Frankie Faison and Moran Atias. (10 p.m. NBC)

“Amy Schumer Growing”: The stand-up comic jokes about being pregnant, her marriage and other examples of growth. (Netflix)

MARCH 20

“Pretty Little Liars: The Perfectionists”: Sasha Pieterse and Janel Parrish bring their characters from “Pretty Little Liars” to a spinoff that’s set in the fictional college town of Beacon Heights, Oregon. The mystery-melodrama filmed in the Portland area, with a cast that also includes Sofia Carson. (8 p.m. Freeform)

“The Act”: What’s being billed a new true-crime anthology series begins with a fact-inspired story starring Patricia Arquette as a mother who is way too involved in her daughter’s health. Joey King plays the daughter. (Hulu)

MARCH 22

“The OA”: The eerie drama about a woman’s disappearance and the strange discoveries she makes about what really happened returns for a second season. Britt Marling stars. Local note: Some scenes were filmed in Oregon. (Netflix)

MARCH 24

“Into the Badlands”: The action series begins the second half of its third and final season. (10 p.m. AMC)

MARCH 25

“Jesus: His Life”: Famed pastor and televangelist Joel Osteen is an executive producer of a four-part series that explores the story of Jesus from the perspective of biblical figures. Theologians, scholars and faith leaders are also interviewed. (8 p.m. History Channel)

“Knightfall”: The Middle Ages-set adventure about the Knights Templar returns for Season 2, with a new cast member, Mark Hamill. He plays, according to the show’s website, “a battle-hardened Knight Templar veteran and initiate master who is tasked with preparing the next generation of men to proudly wear the iconic red cross on their chests and become ‘God’s Executioners.’” (10 p.m. History Channel)

MARCH 27

“Jane the Virgin”: The much-loved telenovela-comedy-drama starring Gina Rodriguez begins its fifth and final season. (9 p.m. The CW)

“Million Dollar Mile”: Tim Tebow hosts a new show in which contestants race to complete a difficult course, and and win $1 million bucks. (9 p.m. CBS)

“What We Do in the Shadows”: A horror comedy, inspired by the movie from Jemaine Clement and Taika Waititi, about vampires who’ve spent the last hundred+ years in Staten Island. Clement created the series, which stars Matt Berry. (10 p.m. FX)

“Happy!”: In one of the more surprising renewals, this dark, weird series about a train wreck of an ex-cop-turned hit man (Christopher Meloni) and an imaginary horse (voiced by Patton Oswalt) was tapped to return for a second season of insanity. (10 p.m. Syfy)

MARCH 28

“Abby’s”: Natalie Morales stars in a new comedy as the owner of a San Diego bar – which is located in her backyard. The cast includes Neil Flynn (“The Middle”) as a regular who’s perfectly happy to get his bar on in a backyard setting. Michael Schur (“The Good Place”) co-created the show. (9:30 p.m. NBC)

MARCH 29

“Hanna”: A new TV series inspired by the movie of the same name, about a girl who tries to flee, as the Amazon website says, “the relentless pursuit of an off-book CIA agent and tries to unearth the truth behind who she is.” The cast includes Mireille Enos and Joel Kinnaman, who you may remember as an indelible duo in “The Killing.” Esme Creed-Miles plays Hanna. (Amazon Prime Video)

“Santa Clarita Diet”: Drew Barrymore and Timothy Olyphant return for Season 3 of yet another dark comedy, this one about a real estate team whose lives get complicated when the wife (Barrymore) develops a zombie-hunger for human flesh. (Netflix)

MARCH 31

“Call the Midwife”: Season 8 of the British-made series premieres. (8 p.m. PBS)

“Mrs. Wilson”: Ruth Wilson stars in a three-part drama inspired by her own family history. The story is set in London and India in the 1930s, 1940s and 1960s, and has to do with Alison Wilson (played by Wilson), who finds out that her supposed happy marriage isn’t what she thought. (9 p.m. PBS)

“Barry”: After a first season that ended on a daringly grim note, the comedy about a hitman who dreams of acting is back for Season 2. Co-creator Bill Hader once more stars, along with a great cast that includes Henry Winkler, Anthony Carrigan, Sarah Goldberg and Stephen Root. (10 p.m. HBO)

“Veep”: The incomparable Julia Louis-Dreyfus and the gifted cast return for the seventh and final season of the political satire. (Time TBD; HBO)

“Trailer Park Boys: The Animated Series”: What was a live-action comedy is now a cartoon. OK, then. (Netflix)

APRIL 1

“DC’s Legends of Tomorrow”: The superhero series returns for the second half of Season 4. (8 p.m. The CW)

“Hostile Planet”: Bear Grylls hosts a new series that shows the life-and-death situations faced by a variety of wildlife around the world. (9 p.m. National Geographic Channel)

“The Twilight Zone”: Jordan Peele (“Get Out”) is an executive producer, and takes over Rod Serling’s duties as host and narrator of a new version of the classic chiller anthology. A stellar roster of guest stars has been announced, including Sanaa Lathan, Steven Yeun, Seth Rogen, Kumail Nanjiani, Allison Tolman, John Cho, Greg Kinnear, Ginnifer Goodwin and more. Expect some updates of vintage “Twilight Zone” episodes, including “Nightmare at 30,000 Feet,” with Adam Scott taking over the role of the terrified airplane passenger originally played by William Shatner. (CBS All Access)

APRIL 2

“The Last O.G.”: Tracy Morgan, Tiffany Haddish and more return for Season 2 of the comedy. (10:30 p.m. TBS)

APRIL 3

“Brockmire”: Hank Azaria’s acerbic baseball broadcaster is back for more innings in Season 3. (Time TBD; IFC)

APRIL 4

“In the Dark”: A new comedy-drama about a woman who’s blind but is a witness to a murder. Perry Mattfield stars. (9 p.m. The CW)

APRIL 5

“Gold Rush: Dave Turin’s Lost Mine”: Oregon’s own Dave Turin, who left Todd Hoffman’s “Gold Rush” crew, is back and starring in his own reality show about trying to find gold in an abandoned mine. (9 p.m. Discovery Channel)

“Chilling Adventures of Sabrina”: Part 2 of the first season brings back Sabrina (Kiernan Shipka), who’s exploring her witchy powers and dealing with a love triangle. (Netflix)

“Our Planet”: A documentary series about the natural world and the wildlife who inhabit it, narrated by Sir David Attenborough and produced in partnership with the World Wildlife Fund. (Netflix)

APRIL 6

“Native Son”: Ashton Sanders stars in a new TV movie adapted from Richard Wright’s classic novel. Suzan-Lori Parks wrote the screenplay, and Rashid Johnson directs. Sanders plays Bigger Thomas, an African American in Chicago, who gets involved with a complicated world of money and privilege. The cast includes Bill Camp, Margaret Qualley, David Alan Grier and Sanaa Lathan. (10 p.m. HBO)

APRIL 7

“Killing Eve”: Golden Globe winner Sandra Oh and Jodie Comer return for Season 2 of last year’s surprise hit. Since the first season ended with Oh’s British government agent, Eve Polastri, stabbing the assassin, Villanelle (Comer), and Season 2 will pick up just where that left off, more suspense and surprises are definitely on the way. Because, obviously, everyone’s favorite psychopath lives to commit more mayhem. (8 p.m. AMC and BBC America)

“The Chi”: Lena Waithe’s drama about people living in Chicago’s south side, and the everyday challenges, dreams and struggles they face returns for Season 2. (10 p.m. Showtime)

APRIL 9

“The Bold Type”: The popular series about young people working at a leading women’s magazine returns for Season 3. (8 p.m. Freeform)

“The Code”: A new legal drama about active duty Marines who are also prosecutors, defense attorneys and investigators. (9 p.m. CBS)

“Reconstruction: America After the Civil War”: Henry Louis Gates, Jr. is an executive producer of a four-hour documentary series that examines the years following the Civil War, and how the promise of freedom for former slaves collided with entrenched attitudes of bigotry and Jim Crow segregation. (9 p.m. PBS)

“Fosse/Verdon”: Sam Rockwell plays Bob Fosse and Michelle Williams is Gwen Verdon in this limited series about the legendary choreographer and renowned dancer whose partnership included marriage and creative collaboration, hitting exhilarating highs and devastating lows along the way. Based on the pilot, this looks like it may be one of the top shows of the year. (10 p.m. FX)

“You Me Her”: The series about a married couple who wind up involved in a three-way relationship with another woman returns for a new season. (10 p.m. Audience)

APRIL 14

“Game of Thrones”: Maybe you’ve heard of this show? It’s been pretty popular for HBO. The eighth and final season premieres tonight, and I’m thinking a few people will tune in. (I know, I know, I’m as funny as a direwolf with rabies.) (9 p.m. HBO)

APRIL 16

“Bless This Mess”: Lake Bell and Dax Shepard star in a new comedy as a couple who decide to ditch their New York lives and move to rural Nebraska for the supposedly simple life. (8:30 p.m. ABC)

APRIL 19

“Vice Special Report: The Future of Work”: A special that examines how traditional work structure is being upended, and the changes that are ahead in the global economy. (10 p.m. HBO)

“Lunatics”: A mockmentary comedy about six characters, who are all played by Australian writer/creator Chris Lilley. (Netflix)

“Ramy”: Ramy Youssef created and stars in this comedy about a first-generation Egyptian-American trying to find a balance between his Muslim heritage and beliefs and life as a young guy in New Jersey. (Hulu)

APRIL 22

“Oregon’s Japanese Americans”: A new “Oregon Experience” documentary that explores the history of Japanese people in Oregon, from pioneer times to the internment of Japanese Americans during World War II, and what came after. (9 p.m. OPB)

“Gentleman Jack”: Suranne Jones (“Doctor Foster”) stars in a British period series with a difference. It’s based on a true story, about a lesbian in the early 1800s who lived her life boldly, engaging in her love affairs with women and speaking her mind. Sally Wainwright (“Happy Valley”) is the writer and director. (10 p.m. HBO)

APRIL 27

“The Son”: Pierce Brosnan returns in the Western series about a family’s history and the dynasty they strive to build. This second season is also the final one for the series. (9 p.m. AMC)

“Not the White House Correspondents’ Dinner”: “Full Frontal” host Samantha Bee returns for the second special to air on the same date as the official White House Correspondents’ Dinner. Expect politically themed comedy, and journalists as guests. (10 p.m. TBS)

APRIL 28

“The Red Line”: This eight-episode event series has the kind of ambition and broad canvas you don’t really expect from CBS. But, based on a preview, it looks as richly textured, ambitious and complex as the city where it’s set, Chicago. The cast includes Noah Wyle, Emayatzy Corinealdi, Noel Fisher and Aliyah Royale. The story – which takes on race, crime, class, gay rights and more -- is set in motion when a white cop shoots an unarmed African American man. The series will be broadcast in two-hour installments over four Sundays. (8 p.m. CBS)

“The Redemption Project With Van Jones”: A new eight-part series explores the restorative justice process. (9 p.m. CNN)

“United Shades of America With W. Kamau Bell”: The comedian and commentator returns for Season 4 of his show, in which travels the country and talks to people about social issues, race, cultural clashes, and more. (10 p.m. CNN)

APRIL 29

“Nature: American Spring: Live”: Juju Chang hosts a three-day event chronicling nature shaking off winter and waking up to spring, at locations around the country. (National premiere is scheduled for 8 p.m. on PBS)

MAY 2

“IZombie”: Rose McIver returns for the fifth and final season of the zombie thriller. (8 p.m. The CW)

MAY 3

“At the Heart of Gold: Inside the USA Gymnastics Scandal”: A documentary that focuses on the sexual abuse scandal involving former Olympic gymnastics team doctor Larry Nassar, and includes interviews with survivors and more. Producers include Steven Ungerleider, an author and psychologist based in Eugene. (8 p.m. HBO)

“Ask Dr. Ruth”: The famed sex therapist Dr. Ruth Westheimer is the subject of a documentary that looks back at her past, as a Holocaust survivor, and her journey toward becoming a household name. (Hulu)

MAY 6

“Chernobyl”: A five-part miniseries drama based on the 1986 nuclear accident stars Jared Harris, Stellan Skarsgard and Emily Watson. (9 p.m. HBO)

MAY 7

“Foster”: A documentary that looks at the world of foster care through the prism of cases from the Los Angeles County Department of Children and Family Services. (8 p.m. HBO)

“The Haves and the Have Nots”: The Tyler Perry-created drama returns for Season 6. (9 p.m. OWN)

MAY 8

“Lucifer”: Fox canceled this stylish series about the devil (Tom Ellis) in contemporary Los Angeles, but Netflix picked it up for Season 4. (Netflix)

MAY 9

“Paradise Hotel”: Kristin Cavallari hosts a new dating competition series. (8 p.m. Fox)

MAY 10

“Marvel’s Agents of S.H.I.E.L.D.”: Yes, this show is still on, and as proof, here it is returning for new episodes. (8 p.m. ABC)

“Wu-Tang Clan: Of Mics and Men”: The influential hip hop group is the focus of a docuseries including interviews and performance footage. (9 p.m. Showtime)

“Sneaky Pete”: Giovanni Ribisi returns for Season 3 of the series about a con man who fakes being part of a family, but is scrambling to hide from his past, and to keep his secrets. (Amazon Prime Video)

MAY 11

“My Dad Wrote a Porno”: A comedy special based on a popular British comedy podcast, in which Jamie Morton reads from actual “erotic” fiction written by his father, under the pen name of “Rocky Flintstone.” (11 p.m. HBO)

MAY 12

“Our Cartoon President”: The animated spoof of the presidency of Donald Trump returns for Season 2. ( 8 p.m. Showtime)

MAY 13

“The Bachelorette”: Just when we weren’t missing this franchise, it returns for another season. (8 p.m. ABC)

“Paid Off With Michael Torpey”: The comedy game show returns to give more contestants a chance to win prize money to pay off their student debt. (10 p.m. truTV)

“Line of Duty”: A new season of the British-made cop thriller begins. (Streaming on Acorn TV)

MAY 14

“What’s My Name | Muhammad Ali”: Antoine Fuqua (“Training Day”) directs this two-part documentary that tells the story of boxing legend Muhammad Ali, using archival footage and clips featuring Ali’s own words. (8 p.m. HBO)

MAY 15

“MasterChef Celebrity Family Showdown”: A two-night special featuring cooking competition between the likes of Tori Spelling, Jennieth Garth, Johnny Weir, Tara Lipinski, Lisa Vanderpump, Nicole “Snooki” Polizzi, Evander Holyfield, Oscar De La Hoya and their teams of family members and friends. (8 p.m. Fox)

MAY 17

“Catch-22”: George Clooney and producing partner Grant Heslov are among the executive producers of a new, six-episode, limited series adaptation of Joseph Heller’s classic satirical novel about World War II. Clooney plays a supporting role, while Christopher Abbott plays Yossarian, the U.S. Air Force bombardier whose desire to get out of dangerous combat runs smack into that bureaucratic nightmare, Catch-22. (Streaming on Hulu beginning May 17)

“Fleabag”: Creator and star Phoebe Waller-Bridge returns for a second season of the dark comedy, this time focusing on, as the press release, says, “a battle she is determined to win: Fleabag vs. God.” (Amazon Prime Video)

“Meghan and Harry Plus One”: Gayle King anchors a special that marks the one-year anniversary of the marriage of Meghan Markle and Prince Harry, who are also expecting their first child. (8 p.m. CBS)

MAY 20

“Beat Shazam”: Jamie Foxx returns to host with Corinne Foxx as d.j. in a new season of the game show. (8 p.m. Fox)

MAY 22

“The Amazing Race”: The globe-trotting reality show returns for another season. (8 p.m. CBS)

MAY 23

“Red Nose Day Special ”: NBC airs a three-hour block of programming in support of Red Nose Day, the global campaign to raise money for working to alleviate child poverty. Celebrities including Kelly Clarkson and Blake Shelton will perform, and other content will spotlight how donations to Red Nose Day are put to use. Other highlights include a mini-sequel to “Four Weddings and a Funeral,” and Jane Lynch hosting a special edition of “Hollywood Game Night.” (8 p.m. NBC)

“The Name of the Rose”: John Turturro, Michael Emerson and Rupert Everett head the cast of a limited series based on Umberto Eco’s novel. (10 p.m. SundanceTV)

“Christina on the Coast”: Christina Anstead, who HGTV viewers watched with her now ex on the series, “Flip or Flop,” appears in a new series that spotlights her design business, life with her new husband, their blended family, and more. (9 p.m. HGTV)

“Elementary”: The modern spin on Holmes and Watson, starring Jonny Lee Miller and Lucy Liu, returns for its seventh and final season. (10 p.m. CBS)

MAY 24

“Pitching In”: Larry Lamb and Hayley Mills are among the stars of a new family drama from Acorn TV and BBC Wales. (Acorn TV)

MAY 26

“Game of Thrones: The Last Watch”: Airing a week after the series final of “Game of Thrones,” this special may help fans deal with their separation anxiety. It promises to give an inside look at the making of the series, featuring crew and cast working in extreme conditions, amid generalized fan frenzy. And you thought the series was dramatic! (9 p.m. HBO)

MAY 27

“The Hot Zone”: Julianna Margulies stars in an adaptation of Richard Preston’s best-seller about the deadly Ebola virus and what happened when it made its way to the U.S. in 1989. (9 p.m. National Geographic Channel)

MAY 28

“Running With Beto”: A documentary that follows Beto O’Rourke’s rise from relative obscurity into a nationally known political figure. (8 p.m. HBO)

MAY 29

“Archer: 1999”: Season 10 of the animated series is a spoof of space dramas. (10 p.m. FXX)

MAY 30

“Lip Sync Battle”: Big Bird turns up to begin a series of new episodes. (10 p.m. Paramount Network)

MAY 31

“Deadwood”: The long-awaited TV movie that picks up the characters from the memorably foul-mouthed HBO Western series, and brings then together to celebrate South Dakota’s statehood. Returning for the movie are Ian McShane, Timothy Olyphant, Molly Parker, Paula Malcomson, John Hawkes, Ken Dickens and more. (8 p.m. HBO)

“Good Omens”: Michael Sheen, David Tennant and Jon Hamm star in a six-part series based on Neil Tennant and Terry Pratchett’s book about angels, demons, and the prospect of a pesky Armageddon. The impressive cast also includes Benedict Cumberbatch, who plays Satan. (Amazon Prime Video)

“When They See Us”: Michael K. Williams, Vera Farmiga and Felicity Huffman (who’s been in the news recently for non-acting reasons) star in a limited series from Ava DuVernay, dramatizing the true-life case of five teenagers of color who were convicted of raping and assaulting a female jogger in Central Park, in 1989. The case led to a national controversy about race and the justice system and only became more heated when the convicted suspects were later exonerated. (Netflix)

-- Kristi Turnquist

kturnquist@oregonian.com 503-221-8227 @Kristiturnquist
